title: 108_hr3717
content:
The "Broadcast Decency Enforcement Act of 2004" increases penalties for obscene, indecent, and profane broadcasts. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to increase penalties for obscene, indecent, and profane broadcasts by broadcast stations or license applicants to a maximum of $500,000 per violation. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to increase penalties for obscene, indecent, and profane broadcasts by broadcast stations or license applicants to a maximum of $500,000 per violation. The amendment also includes a provision that limits the forfeiture penalty to $500,000 for each violation if the violator is found to have uttered obscene, indecent, or profane material. SEC. 3. ADDITIONAL FACTORS IN INDECENCY PENALTIES; EXCEPTION. Section 503(b)(2) of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include new factors for the Commission to consider in cases of violations involving obscene, indecent, or profane material. These factors include the nature of the material, whether it was live or recorded, scripted or unscripted, and the violator's opportunity to review or basis to believe the content. The Commission will consider new factors in violations involving obscene, indecent, or profane material, such as the nature of the programming, whether it was live or unscripted, the audience size, and if it was part of a children's program. Additionally, the violator's ability to pay will be assessed based on whether they are a company or individual, and the size of the company if applicable. The FCC will consider new factors in violations involving obscene, indecent, or profane material, including the nature of the programming, audience size, and presence in children's programs. A broadcast station licensee not owned or controlled by a network organization won't be penalized for airing such material if it was part of live or recorded programming provided by the network without prior review opportunity. The FCC will define the term 'network organization' for violations involving obscene, indecent, or profane material. Licensees or permittees will not be penalized if they had no reasonable basis to believe the programming would contain such material. SEC. 4. INDECENCY PENALTIES FOR NONLICENSEES. Section 503(b)(5) of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to redesignate subparagraphs and make changes to provisions regarding operators and tower determinations. Section 503(b)(5) of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include provisions related to determining if a person willfully or intentionally made obscene, indecent, or profane utterances broadcast by a station licensee or permittee. SEC. 5. DEADLINES FOR ACTION ON COMPLAINTS. Section 503(b) of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include a new paragraph regarding allegations of broadcasting obscene, indecent, or profane material. Within 180 days of receiving such an allegation, the Commission must issue a notice to the licensee or permittee, issue a notice of apparent liability, or notify the parties involved in writing. The Commission must take action within 270 days of receiving an allegation of broadcasting obscene, indecent, or profane material. If the licensee or permittee does not pay a penalty or settle with the Commission, the Commission will issue a forfeiture penalty or notify in writing that no penalty will be issued. SEC. 6. ADDITIONAL REMEDIES FOR INDECENT BROADCAST.

The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to allow the Commission to require broadcast stations that air obscene, indecent, or profane material to also broadcast public service announcements for children. These announcements must reach an audience up to 5 times larger than the audience reached by the inappropriate material. SEC. 7. LICENSE DISQUALIFICATION FOR VIOLATIONS OF INDECENCY PROHIBITIONS. Section 503 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include a new subsection (d) regarding License Disqualification for Violations of Indecency Prohibitions. If a broadcast station licensee is found to have broadcast obscene, indecent, or profane material and has paid a forfeiture penalty or had a court order for payment finalized, the Commission will consider this in future proceedings. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include a new subsection (d) regarding License Disqualification for Violations of Indecency Prohibitions. The Commission will consider whether the broadcast of material demonstrates a lack of character or other qualifications required to operate a station. SEC. 8. LICENSE RENEWAL CONSIDERATION OF VIOLATIONS OF INDECENCY PROHIBITIONS. License renewal consideration of violations of indecency prohibitions under Section 309(k) of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to treat violations as serious if a forfeiture penalty has been paid or ordered by a court. License renewal violations of indecency prohibitions under Section 309(k) of the Communications Act of 1934 will be considered serious if a forfeiture penalty has been paid or ordered by a court. If there is a violation, it will be treated as a serious violation for license or permit renewal. License revocation for violations of indecency prohibitions is addressed in Section 9. License revocation for violations of indecency prohibitions is addressed in Section 312 of the Communications Act of 1934, which allows for license revocation if a broadcast station repeatedly airs obscene, indecent, or profane material despite receiving notices and penalties. If a licensee fails to pay a forfeiture penalty and the order becomes final, the Commission may start a proceeding to consider revoking the station license or construction permit. This does not limit the Commission's authority to initiate such proceedings under subsection (a) of the Communications Act of 1934. SEC. 10. REQUIRED CONTENTS OF ANNUAL REPORTS OF THE COMMISSION. Each annual report submitted by the Federal Communications Commission must include the number of complaints received alleging broadcast content to be obscene, indecent, or profane, the status of those complaints, and the number of notices issued by the Commission under relevant sections of the Communications Act of 1934. The annual report must include the number of complaints received regarding obscene, indecent, or profane broadcast content, along with the status of those complaints and the number of notices issued by the FCC under the Communications Act of 1934 to enforce regulations on broadcasting such material. The annual report must detail the broadcasting of obscene, indecent, or profane material, including forfeiture orders issued by the FCC and whether licensees have paid the penalties or if the Department of Justice was involved in collecting them. The annual report must include details on FCC forfeiture orders for broadcasting obscene, indecent, or profane material. It should also cover whether the Department of Justice has taken action to collect penalties, the timeline for such action, and any resulting payments. SEC. 11. GAO to study complaints about indecent broadcasting. The General Accounting Office will study complaints about broadcasting obscene, indecent, and profane material to the FCC, including the number of complaints, final agency actions, response times, investigation mechanisms, and communication with complainants. A report on the study's results will be submitted to the Committee on Commerce, Science within one year of the Act's enactment. The Act requires a report on complaints about broadcasting obscene material to be submitted to the Senate and House committees. SEC. 12. SENSE OF THE CONGRESS. Congress urges broadcast television station licensees to reinstate a family viewing policy similar to the one from 1975 to 1983. SEC. 13. IMPLEMENTATION. SEC. 13. IMPLEMENTATION. The Commission will create regulations to implement the amendments within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Act and its amendments do not apply to material broadcast before the Act's enactment date. Section 708 of the Communications Act of 1934 applies to this Act and its amendments.
